author: uri_bloxroute
content:
I agree and disagree.
**Agree** that the conversations on The Merge and upcoming changes do not propagate well to the broader ETH community, and honestly, the mining community is even more of "an outsider" than the average eth-head

**Disagree** that this is the issue here, since the gas limit is very different:
- Pool#1-3 (58%) adjust the gas limit based on what they think is best
- pools#4-6 (12%) play a minor role 
- smaller pools (30%) are not even participating today, basically adjust when the top pools change it 

Very few ppl know that ~40% of the hashpower (Sparkpool, Babel pool, and a few others) had been trying to increase the gas limit for **months** now - just check the blockchain.
I assume Ethermine changed their mind, and au viola, we have a new gas limit.
Is it good? Is it bad? should we increase it more or decrease? there's no way to actually judge the sentiment among core devs, let alone in the greater community.

author: pipermerriam
content: It's a bad thing if it is a distraction and using a token for in-protocol governance of the gas limit has multiple problems that feel complex enough that the complexity of the solution feels entirely unreasonable to justify for the "problem" it is trying to solve.   The problem exists but it isn't huge so I'm not suggesting there is no problem at all.  To list a few of the significant complexities....  initial distribution of the token is a nightmare....  the token being a financial instrument introduces perverse incentives into the governance of the protocol gas limit... there are very few people who can make an educated assessment of what a safe gas limit is and there is no way to ensure that those people are the people holding the tokens....     So this proposal feels like a distraction.

author: pipermerriam
content: (if you want to dive into any of those "complexities", lets pick one rather than trying to respond to all of them at the same time)

author: pipermerriam
content:
A: initial distribution
B: perverse incentives due to the token being fungible and worth something
C: ensuring that the people voting with the tokens are actually the people who know enough to make an informed decision
